description.text: Baby Tentacle was made with 123D Creature.    Aligned to the build plate in Makerware. I cut off the very bottom in Netfabb so that it would print without needing supports. RepG Sailfish did the slicing and gave me a great print!

I printed this at 200 percent scale. 100 micron resolution in PLA with 3 shells. No support was needed. The output of 123D creature is pretty hi poly so I only uploaded the smaller stl. The r10 sailfish version of RepG handled the bigger stl without an issue. Big thanks to the sailfish team for making my printer more awesome!

title: A great marble pump with crank handle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I build this as a game for my children. They love it. The parts were designed with freeCAD, to chek the assembly I load all stl files to Blender.

All parts were bonded to a wooden panel with Epoxy.
First I glow the spirals together. For this there is a hole 10mm inside, so you can put the spirals on a shaft. The bearing brackets do have a recess, this should be on the side of the Spiral Bevel Gear. The marbles should have a diameter of about 15mm. All Parts are designed in a way that they need only a litle bit support material.

comments.text: So I printed it out but I'm having trouble getting it to work. I'm using the standard 16 mm marbles. The problem is that the marble has no resistance at the entry point so it never starts up the corkscrew. Instead it gets pushed back up the on ramp. Any suggestions?

comments.text: I have had the same Problem. Try to fill somme more Marbles into the Pump, so the Marbles were pressed into the Pump.

comments.text: That would probably work but I need it to do one without extra marbles.

author: berschwer

title: Magsafe Macbook Charger Cable Repair Box

description.text:
My dog decided that my Macbook Magsafe charger looked like a pretty good $100 snack, so she chewed the magnet bit off of it. Rather than spending the money for a new one, I decided to buy a replacement cable on Amazon for $7. Didn't want to bother with all Apple's glue and risk not being able to put it back together well, so I whipped up this box that holds onto the cable wrap hinges that I never use anyways. Here's a link to the replacement Magsafe cable I bought on Amazon:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AOICCJK/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 The holes I put in it are for a M5 20mm(ish) or longer bolt, but I included the blender files before and after the boolean cuts so you can easily modify it. I also want to note that this is the charger from a 13" 2010 Macbook Pro. I have no idea if they have different Magsafe chargers. Here are some measurements so you can easily make sure yours is the right size: Charger block: 74.2mm x 74.2mm x 28.3mm
Space inside hooks: 38.4mm
Hook: 4.5mm x 14.2mm

title: Diffusor to bring air into your tank

description.text:
What to do if you want to ventilate your tank better allowing to bring more air into the water for your fishes?  
Easy either buy an additional costly air pump with some equipment or attach a diffusor to your current waterpump.  
If you deside to choose the second method print it attach it done.  
The diffusor is available in different sizes. the number at the end of the filenmae describes the inside diameter of your hose in milimeters. Make sure that the air hose you attach is not submerged otherwise you can't pull air into the aquarium.  
The connection for the air hose is allways designed for a hose with 4mm inside diameter.
Make sure you print with supports otherwise the air hose connector can not be printed.

comments.text: You saved my day. Thanks.
comments.author: Outbreak

comments.text: Tried the 18mm one this arvo in my aquaponics barrel with a pond pump. Had it mounted about 3" under the surface and tried varying water flows but couldn't get it to suck air. It just didn't seem to be creating enough of a pressure drop to suck air in. If I blew very lightly into the air hose then it would diffuse as intended but unfortunately at the 18mm size I couldn't get it to happen even with 1000L/hr pump. I found that conventional venturi designs worked much more reliably. Maybe the smaller designs work (12mm or 14mm)?

Specialy when you decide to print it with a infill that leaves a lot of air inside the part.

Well once you start off with a ring/circle your going to want to place a very small circle (which will become the cutout for the teeth) with its center point just outside of the ring/circle and intersecting the rings/circles rim. From here your going to want to give a circular patter around the rings/circles center point at an x amount of times. for a cool touch you can just round off the edges of the teeth. I would supply a vid but i dont have the materials to make one and i dont believe there's one on making gears yet, but i hope this was sufficient
Matt 8-)

comments.text:
Hi, Cant thank you enough, im in uk, have davinci AIO combo, (scanner sucks), been printing PLA with great prints, but decided to use ABS for its heat/strengh properties, for RC motors. (tried to post on you tube but the post option was blanked out)..
Just could not get the ABS to print/stick/ I thought i had purchased a bad filament, turns out that even with the ZEROCART adapter, my 1.1.4 davinci keeps its ABS settings of 212' extruder, 90' for the bed, tried car feeler gauges, the paper slide trick, hairspray, painters tape, alla pain in the rear section.
Then I came across your THINGIVERSE channel, downloaded the test prints and set about following your footsteps to adjust the bed.
If adjusted too close the extruder will jump, as it cant push the filament through, but .
IT WORKED, no glue, no mess, or gunk to clean off the bed, just perfect prints.
the arms i printed are just a tad over 8 1/2" long, printed corner to corner, perfectly smooth sides.
just one thing now, I have to put weights on the finished print, untill it cools, as the middle releases from the bed it tends to bow slightly, so this method keeps it straight till cool....
many thanks, regards bob

comments.text: Leaves a mess on the bottom of the print but more important, I find it tends to insulate the print from the heat of the bed. So it has to be cleaned off after every print for best heat bed results.

comments.text:
Excellent.
Using this technique helps larger prints as well, especially square prints. I've found this technique keeps the corners from warping up by making the corners stick better to the heated bed. I still recommend some glue in the corners of the print to help keep it down.

Yep, that is warping.
Glue can only do so much. Raft may be necessary or adjust the bed for that 0.18 width in my video so that first layer really flattens out.
Also see if it's only one corner, then move the print on the bed away from that point. The heat of the bed may not be hot enough at that corner.

description.text:
Ever wanted an amphora in your tank?  
Go ahead and print one.

Important!!!!  
PLA and other plastics have a similar density like water. This means that the print could float. Specially when you use only a small percentage of infill.  
Due to that fact you either need to glue the amphora into your tank (preferably before filling it), weight it down with maybe a stone or screw it onto a rock or something you place in the tank.

description.text: This print was increased 2.5 actual size and looks nice. Now I need to print many as all of our friends want one. This one is almost 6 inches tall and stands on its own.
made at 2.5 times the size. On a 6 x 6 heated bed.

I took the original T-800 model, cut it off, and hollowed it out to make space for a small USB hub. Also, I made special LED housing pieces for the eyes, to print with transparent material.  
It doesn't seem to be self-aware yet which is a bit disappointing but good I guess. :D

I used a shimmering bronze coloured PLA for this thing printed in 0,200 mm layer height. With the face tilted backwards this model prints great without supports. Basically you should be able to fit any small compact 2-4 port hub in there. I bought a couple of LED lighted charging cables and connected them to the hub. Routed the cables folded into the eye pieces which I printed in transparent PET (0,300 mm layers).   
Next time I print this I'll scale up to 125% so it can better accommodate the USB hub I got. It would also make the skull look more life size.   
Sliced with CraftWare and printed on a CraftBot.  
Update: Painted it with Viva Inka Gold in graphite and silver. Noob paint job but it's OK :)

title: Reusable Keurig Cup /w Filling Stand & Coffee Scoop

description.text:
Improved!  More robust filter basket and now with coffee scoop and filter holder!  ;-)  
I like my coffee filtered through paper.  It just tastes better to me. The metal screen on the reusable Keurig filter left me wanting... and it was too clumsy to use with the EZ Cup filters I like.  
I designed a reusable cup with an integrated basket for good filter drainage. There is also a stand which holds the cup securely while being filled with coffee.   
I buy EZ Cup paper filters from e-bay.  They were cheap.

I use a Makerbot Replicator Dual. Object fill = 10%
Layer height = .27
Number of shells = 1 The feed rate is 60mm/s with acceleration turned on. This allows better bridging. There is a significant bridge inside the cup. I highly recommend you print the test bridge I provided. It is just a test print. It is the entire bridge portion of the design in a quicker print meant for testing/calibrating your printer. I found using a 60mm/s feed rate eliminated droop. My 42mm long, 0.5mm wide, and 2mm high bridges were perfect. The disk printed with the cap needs to be glued (I use PVC cement) to the inside of the cap. Make sure the smooth part faces the outside. This is where the rubber seal of the hot water spout will mate with the cap, so it needs a smooth surface. This is the main reason this was not printed as one piece with support.

comments.text: 200 degree water comes out of the keurig onto whatever quality plastic you used in making this.  It most certainly leeches from the plastic and gets ingested.  Please read up on the plastics your going to use.
comments.author: kilobit

comments.text: kilobit, I'm surprised someone with your sentiments hasn't shown up sooner. ;-)  It's nice to see that you guys are rare.
comments.author: kilobit

comments.text:
This thing printed just great the first time. But I wonder Why did you print the cap in two pieces? Too much overhang?.
I may have picked a bad day to quit sniffing airplane glue, but can I use it to glue the cap pieces? Or is it toxic?
Also, it seems a little silly to be worrying about bacterial buildup on a coffee steamer. dont these things get sterilized every time you use them?
comments.author: TomW

comments.text: Yes, the cap is in two pieces because it didn't print well as one.  It kept trying to print the inner diameter of the center opening in mid air. :-/  So I made that piece a separate disk to be glued on.
comments.author: TomW

comments.text: Our Keurig model has a raised ridge that interferes with the flange and lid. The easy fix is to print this thing as designed, then just shave off one of the three flanges, and one of the lips on the cap. The ridge then slips right between the filter cone rim and the cap, and the whole thing sits in the machine properly.
comments.author: mesheldrake

comments.text: I can easily edit the code to do what you need.  Approximately how many degrees of the flange circle need to be cut back?  I could remove just enough and move the interlocks.  I don't think you'll have a great seal with only 120 degrees of the cap being held down.
comments.author: mesheldrake

comments.text: Puh-leeze don't post that I'm poisoning myself with ABS or PVC cement.  :-)   ABS is used everywhere from carpets (meaning we probably breath ABS dust) to eating utensils.  Heck, the original reusable Keurig cup is probably ABS.  PVC cement is extensively used in our water supplies.

This is version 2 of my original Ball and Chain and prints as 1 piece and can be printed with no support.  
I just created this as a funny little gift for a friend at work who just got married. The ring actually fits my finger but if your finger is smaller or larger you will need to do some re-sizing if you actually want it to fit your finger. I think I am like a size 8.  
I wanted to be able to print without support so split the ball. I printed with 10% fill and the top came out a bit messy so maybe more infill would fix this. Also as you can see the ball isn't attached to the chain. You have to cut the last ring post print to put them together. Maybe someone has a better idea of how to print this all into a single piece?

comments.text: I printed mine with PLA at .2mm layer height with support material (at 15%) on the buildplate. Print speed was at 50mm/sec, and I ended up using 20% infill. Turned out pretty great, but I'd recommend using more support material, and possibly either slowing down the print speed or using a smaller layer height to get finer results. I noticed that the ball would rock back and forth slightly during the print because the support material didn't really have much of an interface with it.

title: Printrbot Jr. Upper & Lower Filament Guides (1.75mm)

description.text:
I was having issues with my filament slipping out of the teeth of the hobbed bolt halfway through a print (Too much twist while unspooling, I guess...).  So I came up with a fix that guides the filament directly into the hobbed bot.  It also replaces the lasercut piece of wood for the extruder idler, and includes pockets for the nylocks (I hated having to bust out a wrench and a screwdriver to tighten those).
I was also having issues with the lower half of the extruder, it looked like there was too much wobble in the channel below the hobbed bolt and above the extruder, so I added in a lower filament guide as well.

• Print. I used 10% Infill, 2 perimeters, 0.2 layer height.

  • You may have to scrape out the inside of the guide to allow the filament to pass smoothly. A jewelers flat-head screwdriver works great.

  • Note the location of your nylocks, you'll probably be pretty close to that when you replace the idler latch.

  • Replace the idler latch.
    • NOTES I admit, it's a bit of a pain to thread in new filament. I unclip the idler, pull the old filament out, thread the new filament in and raise the latch to the almost locked position, so I can push the filament through the extruder and see it come out the nozzle, then latch it. I may be working on this again if any other problems manifest, but for now it works pretty well for my needs.

HEADS UP This is a major pain in the ass to install, since (for me at least) it required I break down the entire laser-cut extruder. I had to remove the extruder motor and gear, the hobbed bolt and big gear, the idler assembly, and the front two laser cut plates. That let me see how far down into the extruder I had to place the guide.

  • Print. I used 10% Infill, 2 perimeters, 0.2 layer height.

  • I had to file down the inside and outsides to get a nice snug fit. Clean it up a bit now, and it's that much easier later. Make sure you try running filament through it, I double checked to make sure it slid through easy.

  • It's designed so that the channel faces to the right, away from the hobbed bolt. Once your extruder is dismantled, try fitting it to see how well it slides. The two little wings are meant to sit right on the little ledge by the hobbed-bolt bearings. It's designed long, so it can be trimmed to fit. I ended up taking about 1CM off the bottom, and rounding the tip (just the tip). Make sure to test your filament through it again. The guide shouldn't move, and you shouldn't feel any resistance.

  • Once that's all set, reassemble it all and try it out. With both of these pieces in place, I've had to change how I load & unload filament. I unlatch the idler, feed through the filament through the idler till about 2CM is sticking out, then slowly begin closing the idler latch. When it's almost closed, I can slide it in the bottom guide, and push it through till I see it extrude. Lock the latch, good to go.
    • NOTES I lucked out, this worked on the first try (yesterday), so your milage may vary. It's been a major pain having longer prints fail because of tangling inside the lower extruder, and I still have no idea what causes it. Too many pauses? Not a high enough temp (i've been running PLA at 220)? High ambient temperature/humidity? Phase of the moon/Solar Flares? Who knows... I made this, and so far, it seems like it's fixed (finished a 10 hour print yesterday, and it's half-way through a 20 print today).

title: Parametric orchid pot (or general plant pot)

description.text: Get air to your roots!

Orchids like a lot of air to their roots yet most orchid pots have solid walls.  
This design lets you generate pots of many shapes and sizes and add holes to the side allowing better air circulation and reducing the chance of the medium becoming rotten.  
This was designed firstly for orchids but since the holes are optional can be used for any potted plant.  
Highly Configurable

Configuration includes:
  • set height/radius
  • set top/bottom curvature
  • add any number of feet, their height and width
  • set size of drainage holes
  • set wall thickness
  • set number of wall holes, their rotation, range of sizes and roundness
24/12/14 - updated to slightly flatten feet improving adhesion to print bed

09/01/15 - Added hole generation script (opens in browser) removing the need for RapCAD and simplifying the process (hooray!). Improved hole generation algorithm. Fixed a bug where holes could overlap.

• To make the basic pot shape open pot.scad, adjust the configuration to suit your needs and render.

  • Open hole_generator.html in your browser. Adjust the settings to your liking ensuring pot height and radius are set to the same values you've used in pot.scad and press generate. A you should see a preview of the holes and some generated OpenSCAD code. Copy the code into OpenSCAD, render (may take a long time) and export the model as an STL saving it as 'cutout.stl' in the same directory as pot.scad.

  • fix the exported STL - I recommend using MeshLab for this step

  • Open pot.scad once more and hit render; the cutout model you've just created will be subtracted from your pot. Export and print!

author: Kivanc

description.text: A spool mount that sits on the top of an aluminium plate Prusa i3

Print two plate mounts and two spool mounts. Cut 2 identical length M6 threaded rods and fit to each, with nuts and bolts, a plate mount and a spool mount. Cut a length of M8 threaded rod to carry your filament spool (with spool adapters - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60723 ) and press fit it into the spool mounts. This does add some weight to the aluminium plate and does make the frame bend backwards. This may affect prints but I am still testing that. Check back to www.sub-design.co.uk/i3build/ to see how that pans out. Ooops! Missed an STL - had two copies of the scad file for the spool mount. Added STL 29th March 2013.

Height: 0.65 inches (1.7 cm)
Thickness: 0.08 inches (2.0 mm)\n ( change dimensions at: http://cookiecaster.com/casts/8502 )

CookieCaster cookie cutters are easily printed on your MakerBot using the standard settings - we recommend using PLA to print and then saran wrap for cutting to make cleanup easy and to prevent any loose plastic from getting in your cookies

I ordered some new PLA from OSPWRD.com, and they came on these bigger spools, so I made some fittings to mount them with bearings on a piece of threaded rod.
I guess I have humidity problems, cause all of the laser-cut spools and coasters I have are all warped to hell, so they don't work all that well.  At least I could scavenge the old ones for the bearings. :D
I also made a stand, but it's kinda junk, so I'll upload that after I rebuild it.

You are going to need: 1 x 1/4"-20 x 12" Threaded Rod (That's what i had on hand, you could go longer I guess).
4 x 1/4"-20 Nuts
2 x 1/4" Washers
2 x 608 Bearings (I think that's the kind of bearing I had, I scavenged them off the printrbot spool coasters).

  • Print two of these, one for each side. I used 25% Infill, 2 Permieters and 0.2mm layer height. I print these kinda fast, so they come out kinda rough. A set of those little diamond files comes in really handy.

  • I place the inside hub on first, then a washer, then a nut, then the knob (you'll see an inset for the washer and the nut on the bottom. Screw it on about 2 inches in (the hub will be loose, and you want to make sure the rounded cup part is pointing in. There is picture below which shows the order of parts.

  • Add on a bearing, one of the sleeves (this centers the threaded rod in the bearing) and a nut.

  • Put your spool on, and assemble the other side the same way. Tighten the knobs so it's comfy, then tighten down the bolts holding the bearings.
    • NOTES The reduction in friction is ridiculous, these things will spin with almost no effort. Plus, at $1.50 for each threaded rod, I've made a set for each spool on hand, so I can quick-change on my desktop stand.

title: Cable Tie Holder for Rapide Lite's

description.text:
Cable tie holder for a countersunk hex nut (4mm). Holds a cable tie for easy cable management for Rapide Lite-models. Printable with no supports or brims. Print 8 copies at the same time so you have one for every hex nut on the chassi. If your worried that the plastic will increase the chance of unstable prints, use on every other two hex nuts. Model in photos are printed with:
0.1mm layer height
0.25mm first layer height

I created the holders using Sketchup 2013. I used https://netfabb.azurewebsites.net/ to fix the models and then printed it on a Rapide Lite 200. 7 pieces took me 40min too print, including warmup-time. While they were still hot i then installed them by unscrewing one nut at a time and placing them in front of the nut before inserting them again.

author: Davidcolsson

title: SMT pick and place vacuum hand picker

description.text: (this is version 2 of this thing. It has a more ergonomically shape). NEW: added a model for a mouth piece that allow to have a stand alone pick and place tool with no vacuum pump. The tube is a flexible silicon aquarium airline from a pet store. The filter is a universal 1/4" automobile fuel filter (filed to fit the airline). This is a single piece design a handle for vacuum hand picker for electronics SMT components. It has two versions, one with a release hole and without release hole (I am using the latter with a foot pedal and a 12V pneumatic valve for better release stability). The printed release hole is intentionally small and you can drill a larger one if you want, or just print the no hole version and drill a hole wherever you want. The handle is compatible with standard industrial blunt needles (available on eBay) and with standard aquarium air hose (use silicon hose for better flexibility, e.g. "TopFin Silicone Airline Tubing"). The files with 'demo' in their name are provided to show the internal details. These are not the files you want to print. I printed it on a Prusa i3V using PLA, 20% infill, 5 top, bottom and vertical shells (in Slic3r) for better air tightness and no material support (otherwise you will block the internal air passage). Air tightness is important for proper operation so you want to test it by holding it under water with the tip blocked and blowing into the hose. If you still see bubble through cracks and holes you may want to increase the number of shells, print slower, make sure you don't under extrude or fill the holes with glue (you can apply vacuum to such the glue into the holes). This is a base design and hopefully others will improve on it. For example, forcing the air to flow near the release hole for minimizing the residual vacuum when released, a built in adjustable valve for regulating the desire lifting force, built in air filter or somehow making this thing ESD safe. The source files include an inkspace .svg file which contains the spline contour of the handle. It was exported in DXF format using the inkspace BetterDxf extension and is require for proper compilation of the scad file.

This started out as an exercise in using Greg Frost's awesome involute bevel gear script http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575, but turned into a rather pleasing worry-ball type thing. It's also clearly influenced by Greg's broken heart http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4683, though this has octahedral gears rather than dodecahedral, so they all mesh with each other and spin. My favorite thing about it is that you can grab two opposite gears and twist them, making the center with the other six gears spin rapidly around.

Print the parts list. I used a stock TOM, printing raftless with zero fill (just a couple extra shells). Skeinforge 35 made some odd slicing decisions, but it didn't affect the outside of the parts. These are good parts to convince you your calibrated printer still needs some tweaking. Use a screw to tap threads into the center block first, because it makes it easier to assemble. No glue needed, the screws should stay tightly in the center block while the gears revolve. Attach the gears, making sure the edges of the cube connect them. If the gears are too tight to spin easily, just unscrew them all a millimeter or two. The OpenSCAD file is highly parameterized to allow easy tweaking (for different proportions, screw sizes, etc.). You can also change the ratio of teeth on the gears, but you'll need to put the desired parameters into gearopt.m and run in Matlab (or Octave) and copy the result into the OpenSCAD file. This is necessary because I couldn't solve the geometry with anything but an iteration loop, which OpenSCAD doesn't handle so well. I used the MCAD library for Greg's involute gears https://github.com/elmom/MCAD.

comments.text: Yes, I am already printing four gears at once. I have a kapton film platform, it's super sticky. The       first layer is fine, sticks perfectly. I also have solidity set to 0, just like it says in your instructions. Problem is, as layers start building up, the corners of the gear teeth that stick out into air are curling up. It still prints and functions, but the gear teeth will curl, and then the next layer placed on top of the curled layer below it, will just flop down, because there is nothing there to support it any more.

bobcar by jyro [created with 3DTin] (based on sketches by adm3dtin, jyro, rschumak)

As I had a couple of MultiStar 1704 motors laying and doing nothing, I've created a small, simple frame to make use of them. The frame has a motor span of 13.5 mm, so the 5" props are the biggest you can fit there. Printed using 50% infill and 2mm shell thickness the frame (main plate) weights 33 grams and seem to be rigid enough. The motor mounting holes are 14mm apart to fit MultiStar 1704 motors. I'll be preparing a version for other motors as well. If you wish you may mount your FC on a avti vibration plate using rubber anti-vibration mounts (e.g. http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=37447&aff=1479188). It seems to help a lot as the small cheap props are hard to balance. For better anti vibration results I have created alternative versions ("_alt" in the file names) of the main frame and FC mount plate). In this variant the battery plate is mounted through the holes in the main frame to the FC plate which is mounted to the main frame through rubber mounts. Additional weight of the battery results in better dumping performance. You may also want to use a mini PDB like this one: http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewitem.asp?idproduct=56831&aff=1479188. It fits the frame well. There are also two additional plates: top cover for the FC (designed with Naze32 in mind) and bottom one to serve as landing skid/battery holder/cover.

After making my SF Bay print, I thought I'd turn to the Hawaiian islands: I lived on Oahu for a time and have many fond memories. I was always shocked by its beauty constrained by size: I'm pretty sure you could drive around it twice in one day if you tried. I used Terrain2STL by Thatcher Chamberlin to generate the printable mesh. Get more info on how to make it over on my blog. Check out the article on 3DPrint.com

Sliced in Makerbot Desktop, Printed on my Makerbot Replicator 1 (Sailfish firmware) with these settings:
  • First layers (water) translucent "Neon Blue" PLA, all later layers (ground) light gray PLA. No raft, no supports.
  • Extruded @ 200 degs, HBP set to 50: Helped with keeping the large flat parts of the ocean from curling.
  • 2 shells, 10% infill, 200 micron.
  • Print speed 120mm/sec, travel 200mm/sec.
  • Each print took anywhere from 2.5-3 hours.

description.text:
Peace Symbol printed in ABS and then cast in bronze. Created for a cousin of mine who I found out likes them. I'm always amazed at how the printed textures turn out when they are cast.
Relatives and friends now mostly only get printed and cast art for birthdays and holidays.
The uploaded version is fairly large but it can be scaled in the x and y axis for smaller medallions. It's best to keep it 2mm thick (z axis) or it gets a little flimsy both in plastic and bronze.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

Mounting bracket for the transmitter from a Polhemus Fastrak Digitizer system. We use this system to digitize the location of sensors when they are worn by a subject using the Brainstorm Toolbox for MATLAB (http://neuroimage.usc.edu/brainstorm/). The transmitter needs to be mounted on the back of a chair, but there isn't an off-the-shelf solution for this problem. We made one. 1/23/15
TransmitterBox_FlatBack_3.14.stl was found to be a bad file, it has been replaced. 1/12/15
Added TransmitterBox_FlatBack_3.14
This is the 'final' version of the model with a flat back. The size of the access holes to allow for easier marking of the pilot hole location. 1/9/15
Added TransmitterBox_CurvedBack_3.13
Printed this out, mounted it and it works great for the chair that I have. Access holes have been increased in size to accommodate a pencil. I'm considering this the 'final' for the curved model. The only minor issue is that there is slightly more play than necessary in the Y direction when the transmitter is installed. Other than that it is great.
The only possible improvement at this time would be to create 4 holes in the bottom of the holder so that you could run some screws up through it and into threaded holes in the transmitter. I think that this is overkill, so I'm going to call this good until someone convinces me otherwise. Share and enjoy. 1/8/15
Added TransmitterBox_CurvedBack_3.11
This model has slightly bigger access holes in the hopes that a pencil will fit through to aid marking. A curved back was also added to accommodate chairs with a curved back.
This model is being printed for further testing. 1/5/15
Version 3.9 is installed on a chair and was used successfully during a subject visit. The researcher loved it. The design will only get better from here.
This model will be replaced once the access hole size has been determined. 12/29/14
Version 3.9 is now in a usable state. This was a modification of version 3.8, which needed the position and size of the cord notch adjusted. I am going to do a final print of this, but test the printout that I modified manually. This was printed in PLA, but would be better in ABS. This is doubly true if your chair back has a curve to it. My test model cracked a bit due to poorly spaced pilot holes, so be careful of that. Please download, print, test and comment regarding this thing. Future Improvements?
I'm happy with this, but I may further modify it to take into account the curve of the chair back I happen to be using. Additionally, marking the lower pilot holes accurately is difficult since the access holes are big enough for a screwdriver, but not a pencil. I may have to address that as well. 12/23/14
Version 3.4 has some issues with hole sizing, so it currently doesn't work. X dimension works, Y is a little sloppy. Walls are a bit thin, will adjust to 3mm vs 2mm. Heights need adjusting as it's all too short at the moment. Developed by Graham Holt (https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=32946354)
Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience (http://www.childrenshospital.org/research-and-innovation/research/labs/laboratories-of-cognitive-neuroscience)
Boston Children's Hospital (http://www.childrenshospital.org/). This object was modeled in FreeCAD (http://www.freecadweb.org/).

If you have a curved backed chair, print the curved back file.
If you have a flat backed chair, print the flat back file. I used 4 brass #6 1/2" wood screws as brass is non-ferrous. This appeared to be the easiest route for me, but you are encouraged to explore other mounting hardware. Use the holder to mark the location of the 4 pilot holes, and drill to an appropriate depth given the thickness of your chair and your mounting hardware. Screw the holder into place and slide in the transmitter.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53940 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=53940

Using the following options: typeface = blocks
left_side_letter = C
right_side_letter = L
top_letter = E

title: BI v2.5 String to Belt Conversion

description.text: You can find the official BI V2.5 Belt Conversion Kit here. My kit was designed before Boots Industries decided to offer a belt upgrade. This is a conversion from string (fishline) to belt for the BI V2.5 from Boots Industries.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FteUXxGRRuA
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MjtJLVtaFhU

(for one tower)
1 x 16 Teeth GT2 Pulley
2 x M3 4mm Grub Screw
1 x 212cm GT2 Belt
4 x F605ZZ bearing
2 x M5 25mm
2 x M5 Nyloc Nut (or self locking)
5 x M3 10mm

All parts are printed in ABS, 0.2mm height, 3 perimeters thick, 100% infill (except the carriage addon, I've printed it down to 20%, strong enough, faster). This was using a 0.35mm nozzle. The belt tensioner is a little tricky to print, the ratchet teeth and belt grooves are so small, have to slow down the print to 10mm/s for their layers. This part put my little Prusa i3 to its limit.

I originally used the existing printed bearing spacers (in red in the photo below), but I discovered that they interfere with the bearing, making it harder to spin, so I included my own spacer, more accurate. The actual pulley is just press fit. You'll need to cut the original bolt flush to the nut. There are seats for the nut and the round head bolt. Before inserting the top pulley assembly on top, be sure to clear the endstop's cable, so it'll not touch moving part, or interferes.

The motor needs to be unmounted to add the flanged bearings holder. See instructione here for removing the original pulley. Use the M3 10mm screws for fastening the bearing holder in place, and M5 25mm with Nyloc nuts for the bearings. Just align the 16 Teeth GT2 Pulley with the flanged bearings.

You'll need to remove the original flag first, it was glued in my case, so I had to break it. You can reuse the flag if it's still in one piece, or use the one provided here. Just clean the parts where the surfaces come in contact. Use the existing screws (the ones for tightening the strings) to anchor it to the original carriage, the 10mm M3 on the bottom end, the 20mm on top. Assembling the ratchet and belt anchor is straightforward. Once the belt is attached to the carriage side, pass it through the lower and upper pulleys, then use the ratchet to fix it in its final position. You can use small clamps to help mounting the belt.

Since the new pulley doesn't have the same diameter, the steps/mm needs to be readjusted. There is various ways to update the value: in the source code for recompilation, from the LCD menu or in the host EEPROM feature. I'll cover only the firmware code update, as you should already know how to do it in LCD or host. The 16 Teeth GT2 Pulley gives me exactly 100 steps/mm. Marlin
Open the Marlin.ino file with the Arduino IDE, locate the defines below in Configuration.h and change accordingly: #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {100,100,100,291} The first 3 values in the array define the X, Y and Z motor steps per mm respectively. The last value is for the extruder. Repetier Open the Repetier.ino file with the Arduino IDE, locate the defines below in Configuration.h and change accordingly: #define XAXIS_STEPS_PER_MM 100.00 #define YAXIS_STEPS_PER_MM 100.00 #define ZAXIS_STEPS_PER_MM 100.00
Enjoy your new belt driven printer!

author: clefranc

description.text:
Version three of the Octopus tablet stand. This one was designed to fit the iPhone 6/6 Plus, iPad Air and a slew of Android devices. There should be just enough room for a case with most devices. I recommend adding a little bit of sticky adhesive to the bottom to keep it nice and secure. I've uploaded a slightly earlier version of the design. It has bit tighter of an opening and slightly more height to it if you find your device is wobbly. Note: the Moto X 2014 is pretty wobbly in it and I would not recommend it at this time. I've printed a copy of this out at Shapeways myself, as I am absent a 3D Printer :( You can find it here if you're in the same boat as I.
http://shpws.me/wIBN

title: Low profile Thingiversal Chess Set - Primordial

description.text:
A compact low-profile Custom Chess set I pieced together for a buddy from some .thing's I found here on Thingiverse.  
I've dubbed it "The Primordial Chess set"  
The pieces fit boards 7.5x7.5" (19x19mm) and larger.  
Many easter eggs abound for your inner-otaku..  
I <3 creative commons!

Knight - shrunken knight from the most excellent Duchman Chess Set by machina  
Rook - a stretched, gated, and fortified version of rm446's Castle Tower Flower Pot  
Bishop - An original primordial design influenced heavily by Steedmaker's Chess - Classic Set Bishop  
Pawn - A simple primordial pawn design   
Queen - a bust of Zenobia, Queen of Palmyra  
& the King - dutchmogul's Lord of the Porcelain Throne sitting upon the Iron Throne from Game of Thrones. The swords on the back of the throne from left to right=Squall's Gunblade from Final Fantasy 8, Heman's Sword of Power from Masters of the Universe, Gut's Dragon Slayer from Berserk, God King's Infinity Blade from Infinity Blade, Cloud's Buster sword from Final Fantasy 7, Iron Sword from Elder Scrolls:Skyrim, Link's Master sword from Legend of Zelda:Twilight Princess.

comments.text: I'm printing one of the pawns and noticed there's a gap built in in the base. Did you add this for adding a weight or magnet?
comments.author: CopperEngineer

comments.text: Hmm. There should NOT be a gap. While yes, I do love putting magnets into chess-sets and other things non-magnetic, I didn't design this particular set that way. This is probably related to your print software, either the PC or the printer firmware, maybe a setting you can modify somewhere in the software or possibly your gcode.
comments.author: CopperEngineer

comments.text: interesting. I don't have any fancy settings for that (although it would be cool). The gap was so optimally placed I thought for sure it was intended. Oh well, it still looks the same on the outside.

comments.text: :D True enough. All the pieces will probably turn out this way for you since I used the same base for all the pieces (2x 3d extrusion objects conjoined) It might be the overlap in the objects that is being handled that way to cause it.

description.text: Minimalist holder for wii sensor bar. Enjoy!

This is Cory, my first attempt in combining a 3D print design with a servo sensor.
Concept derived from the idea of tomographic reconstruction, as a way to evoke the integrals of a 3 dimensional form.The main objective of tomography is to acquire the internal workings of an object without actively cutting or dissecting it. Taking the fundamental idea of parallel waves penetrating through an object that can be reformatted in multiple planes, I attempted to deliver a "tomogram” in a 3D format instead of a 2D imagery.
  • He's assembled from individual planes without using glue or tape.
  • Two micro servos are inserted to make his wings flap, with a soft pot. as the controller(red board)
It is not my intention to download this model, is very simple , I just want to tell you how I solved a simple problem with 3d :)

this is a simple block for testing dualstrusion here is an little tutorial for set up dualstrusion in slic3r 1.1.7
  • open silc3r
  • tab: printer Settings/General Capabilities 2
  • tab: Set X,Y offset for 2. Extruder
  • tab: File/Combine Multi-material STL files
  • open 35X35 1
  • open 35X35 2
  • cancel
  • save amf file
  • tab: plater/Add
  • open the amf file
  • tab: plater Export G-code
  • load Gcode in your host software
  • good luck

title: Clips for fixing twisted bag strap! (OpenSCAD)

description.text:
I wanted to design and print some clips to put on my bag straps so they don't get all twisted up near the metal rings that connect the bag and strap together. (as shown in the photo)
This is my VERY VERY FIRST OpenSCAD attempt! Hopefully it works and you find it useful too!

x - width of clip
y - distance between the centres of the circular holes
z - height/thickness of clip They should be printed on their sides, but I haven't got my head around how to rotate them 90 degree in the code yet. The clips were designed to slide and lock together internally.

Simple 3d printed base in which wooden cilinders can be attached to use as a stand for loudspeakers. I used 23mm wooden rods which were 250mm in length.  
In the base are 2.5mm (M3) holes to attach an additional wooden plate if needed to make the base even more stable. Also, I attached an additional STL for 3d printed feet.
Printed on 200 micron with ColorFabb Standard Black 1.75mm PLA. 20% honeycomb infill with 3 vertical walls and 5 horizontal walls for the bottom and top.
